items.content: A landslide triggered by heavy rain destroyed an entire village in Sudan’s Darfur, killing more than 1,000 people.

items.title: Sudan landslide kills at least 1,000 people, rebel group says
items.standfirst: Landslide destroyed a village in the Marra mountains area of western Sudan and left only one survivorMore than 1,000 people were killed in a landslide in western Sudan on Sunday, according to a rebel group that controls the area.The landslide, which followed heavy rain, destroyed a village in the Marra mountains area of western Sudan and left only one survivor, said the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM). Continue reading...

items.title: 'Massive' Sudan landslide kills more than 1,000 in Darfur, rebel group says
items.standfirst: A rebel group said Monday that a "devastating" landslide had engulfed a village in war-torn Sudan's Darfur region, killing "all village residents" – more than one thousand people – except for one person, and appealed for the "urgent" intervention of international aid organisations.
items.content: A rebel group said Monday that a "devastating" landslide had engulfed a village in war-torn Sudan's Darfur region, killing "all village residents" – more than one thousand people – except for one person, and appealed for the "urgent" intervention of international aid organisations.

items.content: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army appeals for UN help to recover bodies from village buried by landslide after heavy rain.

items.title: More than 1,000 feared dead in Sudan landslide, rebel group says
items.standfirst: More than 1,000 people are feared dead after a landslide in a village in western Sudan, the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM) has said.
items.content: More than 1,000 people are feared dead after a landslide in a village in western Sudan, the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM) has said.

ai_summary: A landslide in Sudan's Darfur region destroyed a village after heavy rainfall, according to reports.
A local armed group reported the landslide, stating it leveled the village in the Marra mountains.
More than 1,000 people are feared dead, with only one survivor reported by the SLM/Army.
The Sudan Liberation Movement/Army appealed for UN help to recover bodies from the buried village.
International aid organizations are being urged to provide urgent assistance to the affected area.

clusters.title: Afghanistan earthquake death toll passes 1,400 as Taliban appeal for aid

items.title: Afghanistan earthquake death toll passes 1,400 as Taliban appeal for aid
items.standfirst: Rescuers search into the night for people trapped under debris of mud and stone homes in steep valleysThe Taliban have called for international aid as Afghanistan reels from an earthquake that killed more than 1,400 people and left thousands more injured.Rescuers searched into the night on Monday for survivors after the 6.0-magnitude quake struck on Sunday destroying entire villages across the country’s eastern Kunar province, which borders Pakistan. Continue reading...

items.title: Rescuers scramble to reach remote areas of Afghanistan as quake toll rises
items.standfirst: Villagers in the quake-hit regions of eastern Afghanistan joined rescue workers Tuesday in a desperate search for survivors of a 6.0 magnitude earthquake that killed more than 1,400 people. Foreign aid has been slashed since the 2021 return of the Taliban and the latest disaster has worsened Afghanistan's protracted humanitarian crisis.
items.content: Villagers in the quake-hit regions of eastern Afghanistan joined rescue workers Tuesday in a desperate search for survivors of a 6.0 magnitude earthquake that killed more than 1,400 people. Foreign aid has been slashed since the 2021 return of the Taliban and the latest disaster has worsened Afghanistan's protracted humanitarian crisis.

items.title: ‘There is death in every home’, families say, after at least 800 killed in Afghanistan earthquake – as it happened
items.standfirst: Several villages in Kunar province ‘completely destroyed’, says public health ministry, as rescue operations take place. This live blog is closedMagnitude 6 earthquake hits eastern AfghanistanHow have you been affected by the earthquake?One resident in Afghanistan’s Nurgal district, one of the worst-affected areas in Kunar, said almost the entire village had collapsed under the force of the earthquake. “Children are under the rubble. The elderly are under the rubble. Young people are under the rubble,” the villager, who did not give his name, told the Associated Press.“We need help here,” he pleaded. “We need people to come here and join us. Let us pull out the people who are buried. There is no one who can come and remove dead bodies from under the rubble.” Continue reading...
items.content: Several villages in Kunar province ‘completely destroyed’, says public health ministry, as rescue operations take place. This live blog is closedMagnitude 6 earthquake hits eastern AfghanistanHow have you been affected by the earthquake?One resident in Afghanistan’s Nurgal district, one of the worst-affected areas in Kunar, said almost the entire village had collapsed under the force of the earthquake. “Children are under the rubble. The elderly are under the rubble. Young people are under the rubble,” the villager, who did not give his name, told the Associated Press.“We need help here,” he pleaded. “We need people to come here and join us. Let us pull out the people who are buried. There is no one who can come and remove dead bodies from under the rubble.” Continue reading...

items.title: At least 800 dead after magnitude-6 earthquake hits eastern Afghanistan
items.standfirst: Rescuers try to reach people trapped under mud and debris while hampered by destroyed roads and steep terrainA powerful earthquake that hit mountainous eastern Afghanistan has left at least 800 people confirmed dead and injured about 2,500, Taliban officials have said as rescuers struggled to reach the worst-hit villages.The magnitude-6 earthquake struck several provinces close to the Pakistan border around midnight on Sunday, with the rugged region of Kunar the most severely affected. There were landslides and flooding. Continue reading...
items.content: Rescuers try to reach people trapped under mud and debris while hampered by destroyed roads and steep terrainA powerful earthquake that hit mountainous eastern Afghanistan has left at least 800 people confirmed dead and injured about 2,500, Taliban officials have said as rescuers struggled to reach the worst-hit villages.The magnitude-6 earthquake struck several provinces close to the Pakistan border around midnight on Sunday, with the rugged region of Kunar the most severely affected. There were landslides and flooding. Continue reading...

items.content: Over 1,400 people have been killed and at least 3,250 others injured after an earthquake hit eastern Afghanistan, according to the Afghan Red Crescent Society.

items.title: At least 800 killed as powerful earthquake rocks Afghanistan
items.standfirst: At least 800 people have been killed and over 1,000 have been injured in Afghanistan after a 6.0-magnitude earthquake hit the country, Taliban officials said Monday.
items.content: At least 800 people have been killed and over 1,000 have been injured in Afghanistan after a 6.0-magnitude earthquake hit the country, Taliban officials said Monday.

ai_summary: A 6.0-magnitude earthquake struck Afghanistan, causing widespread destruction in the eastern region.
The death toll has exceeded 1,400, with thousands more injured, according to the Taliban.
Rescuers are struggling to reach survivors in remote, mountainous areas affected by the quake.
The Taliban has appealed for international aid to assist with rescue and recovery efforts.
The earthquake destroyed entire villages, hindering rescue efforts due to difficult terrain.

clusters.title: What's behind North Korea's Kim Jong Un travel to Beijing?
clusters.neutral_headline: Kim Jong Un, Putin, and Xi Jinping meet in Beijing

items.title: What's behind North Korea's Kim Jong Un travel to Beijing?
items.standfirst: Kim Jong Un, flying North Korean flags, has arrived at Beijing Railway Station ahead of a massive military parade marking 80 years since the end of World War II. He will join Chinese President Xi Jinping, Vladimir Putin, and other leaders at the event in Tiananmen Square, where China will showcase its military strength. FRANCE 24's Douglas Herbert has more on the stakes of this visit.
items.content: Kim Jong Un, flying North Korean flags, has arrived at Beijing Railway Station ahead of a massive military parade marking 80 years since the end of World War II. He will join Chinese President Xi Jinping, Vladimir Putin, and other leaders at the event in Tiananmen Square, where China will showcase its military strength. FRANCE 24's Douglas Herbert has more on the stakes of this visit.

items.title: Kim Jing Un travels to Beijing to attend a massive military parade
items.standfirst: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has arrived in Beijing by train on Tuesday to attend a military parade with his Chinese and Russian counterparts, North Korea's state media reported. The event could potentially demonstrate three-way unity against the United States. Kim and Russian President Vladimir Putin are among the 26 world leaders who’ll join Chinese President Xi Jinping to watch Wednesday’s massive military parade in Beijing that commemorates the 80th anniversary of the end of World War II and China’s fight against Japan's wartime aggressions. FRANCE 24's Jan Camenzind Broomby has more from the region.
items.content: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has arrived in Beijing by train on Tuesday to attend a military parade with his Chinese and Russian counterparts, North Korea's state media reported. The event could potentially demonstrate three-way unity against the United States. Kim and Russian President Vladimir Putin are among the 26 world leaders who’ll join Chinese President Xi Jinping to watch Wednesday’s massive military parade in Beijing that commemorates the 80th anniversary of the end of World War II and China’s fight against Japan's wartime aggressions. FRANCE 24's Jan Camenzind Broomby has more from the region.

items.content: The two leaders are seeking to promote "a more just and reasonable global governance system".

items.content: Chinese leader Xi Jinping welcomed Russian President Vladimir Putin as an “old friend” as the two began a series of meetings Tuesday at a time when their countries face both overlapping and differing challenges from the United States.

items.content: It is a big week for Xi Jinping, who will host Vladimir Putin and Kim Jong Un in Beijing at a massive military parade.

items.title: North Korea’s Kim heads to Beijing as Putin and Xi hail ‘old friend’ ties

Chinese President Xi Jinping hailed Russian President Vladimir Putin as an “old friend” as the two leaders held talks in the Chinese capital.

items.title: Xi’s Speech, Advanced Drones in Focus at China’s Military Parade
items.standfirst: President Xi Jinping is set to stage a major parade to mark 80 years since the end of World War II — and showcase China’s growing diplomatic sway and military might.
items.content: President Xi Jinping is set to stage a major parade to mark 80 years since the end of World War II — and showcase China’s growing diplomatic sway and military might.

ai_summary: Kim Jong Un arrived in Beijing to attend a military parade with Xi Jinping and Vladimir Putin.
The parade commemorates the end of World War II and China's fight against Japan.
Putin and Xi Jinping discussed strengthening ties, calling them "unprecedented".
The meeting could demonstrate unity against the United States, according to reports.
The event is one of the largest military parades ever staged in Beijing.

clusters.title: Belgium to recognise Palestinian state at UN and sanction Israel – Middle East crisis live
clusters.neutral_headline: Belgium to recognize Palestinian state, impose sanctions

items.title: Belgium to recognise Palestinian state at UN and sanction Israel – Middle East crisis live
items.standfirst: Foreign minister says move is not aimed at Israeli people but ‘ensuring their government respects international and humanitarian law’At least 63,633 Palestinian people have been killed and 160,914 others injured in Israeli attacks on Gaza since 7 October 2023, the Gaza health ministry said in a statement on Tuesday.At least 76 Palestinian people, including 12 aid seekers, were killed in the last 24 hours alone, the ministry said. Continue reading...
items.content: Foreign minister says move is not aimed at Israeli people but ‘ensuring their government respects international and humanitarian law’At least 63,633 Palestinian people have been killed and 160,914 others injured in Israeli attacks on Gaza since 7 October 2023, the Gaza health ministry said in a statement on Tuesday.At least 76 Palestinian people, including 12 aid seekers, were killed in the last 24 hours alone, the ministry said. Continue reading...

items.title: Belgium to recognise Palestinian state, with conditions
items.standfirst: "This is not about punishing the Israeli people, but rather about ensuring that its government respects international and humanitarian law," said Belgium's foreign minister
items.content: "This is not about punishing the Israeli people, but rather about ensuring that its government respects international and humanitarian law," said Belgium's foreign minister

items.title: Belgium says it will recognise Palestinian state at upcoming UN General Assembly
items.standfirst: After recent announcements by France, the UK, and Canada, Belgian Foreign Minister Maxime Prevot on Tuesday said his country will recognise the State of Palestine at the United Nations General Assembly this month, adding that it will impose "firm sanctions" on the Israeli government amid the "humanitarian tragedy" unfolding in Gaza.
items.content: After recent announcements by France, the UK, and Canada, Belgian Foreign Minister Maxime Prevot on Tuesday said his country will recognise the State of Palestine at the United Nations General Assembly this month, adding that it will impose "firm sanctions" on the Israeli government amid the "humanitarian tragedy" unfolding in Gaza.

items.title: Belgium announces it will recognise Palestinian state
items.standfirst: The Belgian government has said it will officially recognise the State of Palestine at the UN General Assembly this month.
items.content: The Belgian government has said it will officially recognise the State of Palestine at the UN General Assembly this month.

items.title: Belgium to recognise Palestinian statehood, impose sanctions on Israel
items.standfirst: FM Maxime Prevot says his country will recognise Palestine this month and impose 12 'firm sanctions' on Israel.
items.content: FM Maxime Prevot says his country will recognise Palestine this month and impose 12 'firm sanctions' on Israel.

ai_summary: Belgium will recognize the State of Palestine at the upcoming UN General Assembly.
The Belgian government will impose sanctions on the Israeli government.
The foreign minister stated the move is not aimed at the Israeli people.
The decision is in response to the humanitarian situation in Gaza.
The Gaza health ministry reported over 63,000 Palestinian deaths since October 2023.

clusters.title: Nestle plunged into turmoil as CEO fired over undisclosed relationship

items.title: Nestle plunged into turmoil as CEO fired over undisclosed relationship
Nestle Fires CEO Laurent Freixe Over 'Romantic Relationship'
items.standfirst: The world's biggest food company, behind Nescafe and Kit Kat, breaks with its chief executive.
items.content: The world's biggest food company, behind Nescafe and Kit Kat, breaks with its chief executive.

items.title: Nestle fires CEO for romantic relationship with colleague
items.standfirst: Swiss food giant Nestle removes its CEO Laurent Freixe after just a year on the job over a relationship with a direct subordinate. We take a closer look. Also in this edition: India's textile export industry comes apart at the seams as US President Donald Trump's tariffs take effect.
items.content: Swiss food giant Nestle removes its CEO Laurent Freixe after just a year on the job over a relationship with a direct subordinate. We take a closer look. Also in this edition: India's textile export industry comes apart at the seams as US President Donald Trump's tariffs take effect.

items.title: CEO fired after 'undisclosed romantic relationship' with employee
items.standfirst: Nestle shares opened down more than 2.5% after the maker of Nescafe, Cheerios, KitKat, and Rolos dismissed its chief executive after an investigation into an undisclosed romantic relationship with an employee.
items.content: Nestle shares opened down more than 2.5% after the maker of Nescafe, Cheerios, KitKat, and Rolos dismissed its chief executive after an investigation into an undisclosed romantic relationship with an employee.

items.content: An investigation found the undisclosed romantic relationship with a direct subordinate violated Nestlé's code of conduct.

items.title: Nestlé sacks CEO over ‘undisclosed romantic relationship’
items.standfirst: Swiss multinational finds Laurent Freixe breached code of conduct as it names Philipp Navratil as his replacementNestlé has dismissed its chief executive, Laurent Freixe, after an investigation into an “undisclosed romantic relationship” with a subordinate that was found to have breached its code of business conduct.The Swiss-headquartered multinational named Philipp Navratil as his replacement. Continue reading...
items.content: Swiss multinational finds Laurent Freixe breached code of conduct as it names Philipp Navratil as his replacementNestlé has dismissed its chief executive, Laurent Freixe, after an investigation into an “undisclosed romantic relationship” with a subordinate that was found to have breached its code of business conduct.The Swiss-headquartered multinational named Philipp Navratil as his replacement. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Nestle dismissed CEO Laurent Freixe after an investigation.
The investigation found an undisclosed romantic relationship with a subordinate.
The relationship violated Nestle's code of conduct.
Philipp Navratil has been named as the new CEO.
Nestle shares opened down more than 2.5% after the announcement.

items.title: Gold price hits record high as investors seek safe haven
items.standfirst: Bullion has nearly doubled in value since 2023 amid global uncertainty and alarm over Donald Trump’s policiesBusiness live – latest updatesThe price of gold has hit a fresh record high, as investors seek out safe-haven assets to protect against inflationary and geopolitical risks.Gold rose above $3,500 (£2,614) an ounce in Asia, surpassing its April peak. It has nearly doubled in value since early 2023. The rally comes as the US dollar has weakened and some central banks add to their gold holdings, ditching US government bonds, known as US treasuries. clusters.title: Bolsonaro trial at Brazil's Supreme Court nears verdicts
clusters.neutral_headline: Bolsonaro coup trial enters final phase

items.title: Bolsonaro trial at Brazil's Supreme Court nears verdicts
items.standfirst: Brazil's Supreme Court will on Tuesday begin hearing closing arguments in the trial of former President Jair Bolsonaro, who faces charges of plotting a coup to remain in power after he lost the 2022 election. The case grabbed global attention after U.S. President Donald Trump denounced it as a "witch hunt" against his ally and retaliated by imposing a 50% tariff on many Brazilian goods.
items.content: Brazil's Supreme Court will on Tuesday begin hearing closing arguments in the trial of former President Jair Bolsonaro, who faces charges of plotting a coup to remain in power after he lost the 2022 election. The case grabbed global attention after U.S. President Donald Trump denounced it as a "witch hunt" against his ally and retaliated by imposing a 50% tariff on many Brazilian goods.

items.title: Brazil's ex-President Bolsonaro faces coup trial — here's what to know
items.standfirst: Brazil's Supreme Court begins the verdict and sentencing phase of Jair Bolsonaro's coup trial Tuesday, with the former president facing a possible 40-year sentence.
items.content: Brazil's Supreme Court begins the verdict and sentencing phase of Jair Bolsonaro's coup trial Tuesday, with the former president facing a possible 40-year sentence.(Image credit: Eraldo Peres)

items.title: Bolsonaro coup trial enters verdict and sentencing phase as US-Brazil ties fray
items.standfirst: Brazil's Supreme Court on Tuesday is set to begin sessions to decide if far-right former president Jair Bolsonaro is guilty of seeking to overturn the 2022 elections to hold on to power. US President Donald Trump denounced the trial as a "witch hunt", and slapped high tariffs on Brazilian exports, plunging relations between the two allies.
items.content: Brazil's Supreme Court on Tuesday is set to begin sessions to decide if far-right former president Jair Bolsonaro is guilty of seeking to overturn the 2022 elections to hold on to power. US President Donald Trump denounced the trial as a "witch hunt", and slapped high tariffs on Brazilian exports, plunging relations between the two allies.

items.content: The former president is accused of plotting a coup to remain in power after he lost the 2022 election.

ai_summary: Brazil's Supreme Court is hearing closing arguments in the Bolsonaro trial.
Bolsonaro faces charges of plotting a coup after losing the 2022 election.
The trial is entering the verdict and sentencing phase.
US President Donald Trump denounced the trial as a "witch hunt".
Trump imposed tariffs on Brazilian exports, straining relations.

clusters.title: Leading scholarly association says Israel is committing genocide in Gaza
clusters.neutral_headline: Israel committing genocide in Gaza, scholars say

items.title: Leading scholarly association says Israel is committing genocide in Gaza
items.standfirst: The world's leading association of genocide scholars declared on Monday that Israel's ongoing actions in Gaza meet the legal definition of the crime. The report by the International Association of Genocide Scholars (IAGS) highlights the 50,000 children Israel has killed or wounded, as well as its widespread attacks on Gaza's healthcare, aid, and educational sectors, and said that Israel's response to Hamas's October 7, 2023, attacks does not solely target the Palestinian militant group but the entirety of Gaza's population.
items.content: The world's leading association of genocide scholars declared on Monday that Israel's ongoing actions in Gaza meet the legal definition of the crime. The report by the International Association of Genocide Scholars (IAGS) highlights the 50,000 children Israel has killed or wounded, as well as its widespread attacks on Gaza's healthcare, aid, and educational sectors, and said that Israel's response to Hamas's October 7, 2023, attacks does not solely target the Palestinian militant group but the entirety of Gaza's population.

items.title: Israel committing genocide in Gaza, world's leading experts say
items.standfirst: The world's leading association of genocide scholars cited several actions by Israel, including attacks on the healthcare sector and the killing of children.
items.content: The world's leading association of genocide scholars cited several actions by Israel, including attacks on the healthcare sector and the killing of children.

items.title: Israel committing genocide in Gaza, world’s top scholars on the crime say
items.standfirst: International Association of Genocide Scholars resolution backed by 86% of members who votedThe world’s leading genocide scholars’ association has backed a resolution stating that Israel’s actions in Gaza meet the legal definition of the crime.Out of the International Association of Genocide Scholars’s (IAGS) 500 members, 28% took part in the vote. Of those who voted, 86% supported the resolution. The resolution states that “Israel’s policies and actions in Gaza meet the legal definition of genocide in article II of the United Nations convention for the prevention and punishment of the crime of genocide (1948).” Continue reading...
items.content: International Association of Genocide Scholars resolution backed by 86% of members who votedThe world’s leading genocide scholars’ association has backed a resolution stating that Israel’s actions in Gaza meet the legal definition of the crime.Out of the International Association of Genocide Scholars’s (IAGS) 500 members, 28% took part in the vote. Of those who voted, 86% supported the resolution. The resolution states that “Israel’s policies and actions in Gaza meet the legal definition of genocide in article II of the United Nations convention for the prevention and punishment of the crime of genocide (1948).” Continue reading...

ai_summary: The International Association of Genocide Scholars declared Israel's actions meet the legal definition.
The report cited attacks on healthcare and the killing of children.
The resolution was supported by 86% of the voting members.
The resolution states Israel's actions meet the definition of genocide.
The association highlighted attacks on Gaza's healthcare and educational sectors.

clusters.title: What Is the GPS Jamming That Disrupted EU Commission President’s Flight?

items.title: What Is the GPS Jamming That Disrupted EU Commission President’s Flight?
items.standfirst: After a plane carrying European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen suffered a GPS navigation outage on its approach to Plovdiv in Bulgaria on Aug. 31, authorities in the country said the signal had likely been jammed by Russia.
items.content: After a plane carrying European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen suffered a GPS navigation outage on its approach to Plovdiv in Bulgaria on Aug. 31, authorities in the country said the signal had likely been jammed by Russia.

items.content: The European Commission said the plane's navigation was disrupted in Bulgaria on Sunday.

items.title: The interesting timing behind Russian GPS jamming claims
items.standfirst: Bulgarian authorities have said they suspect Russia of jamming the GPS system of the jet carrying the EU Commission president on Sunday.
items.content: Bulgarian authorities have said they suspect Russia of jamming the GPS system of the jet carrying the EU Commission president on Sunday.

items.title: Russia suspected of GPS interference after EU Commission president's plane 'forced to land using paper maps'
items.standfirst: A plane carrying European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen suffered GPS jamming as a result of suspected Russian interference, an EU spokesperson has confirmed to Sky News.
items.content: A plane carrying European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen suffered GPS jamming as a result of suspected Russian interference, an EU spokesperson has confirmed to Sky News.

The plane was forced to land using paper maps.
The European Commission confirmed the GPS disruption.

clusters.title: Zack Polanski wins Green party leadership election
clusters.neutral_headline: Zack Polanski wins Green party leadership election

items.title: Zack Polanski wins Green party leadership election
items.standfirst: Candidate defeats Adrian Ramsay and Ellie Chowns to lead Greens in England and Wales with vision for ‘eco-populism’ movementZack Polanski has won the election to lead the Green party in England and Wales, with a big mandate for the party to adopt his vision to become a mass membership “eco-populism” movement directly taking on Reform UK.Polanski, who was the party’s deputy leader and is a Green member of the London Assembly, defeated Adrian Ramsay and Ellie Chowns by 20,411 to 3,705 votes in a ballot of party members. Ramsay and Chowns, who were standing as a co-leadership team, are two of the Greens’ four MPs. Continue reading...
items.content: Candidate defeats Adrian Ramsay and Ellie Chowns to lead Greens in England and Wales with vision for ‘eco-populism’ movementZack Polanski has won the election to lead the Green party in England and Wales, with a big mandate for the party to adopt his vision to become a mass membership “eco-populism” movement directly taking on Reform UK.Polanski, who was the party’s deputy leader and is a Green member of the London Assembly, defeated Adrian Ramsay and Ellie Chowns by 20,411 to 3,705 votes in a ballot of party members. Ramsay and Chowns, who were standing as a co-leadership team, are two of the Greens’ four MPs. Continue reading...

items.title: Former actor Zack Polanski elected leader of the Green Party
items.standfirst: London Assembly member Zack Polanski beats Green MPs Adrian Ramsay and Ellie Chowns, who ran as joint candidates.
items.content: London Assembly member Zack Polanski beats Green MPs Adrian Ramsay and Ellie Chowns, who ran as joint candidates.

ai_summary: Zack Polanski won the Green party leadership election.
He defeated Adrian Ramsay and Ellie Chowns.
Polanski is a London Assembly member.
He aims to lead the Greens in England and Wales.
Polanski's vision is for an "eco-populism" movement.

clusters.title: Thousands protest in Indonesia as military deployed in capital
clusters.neutral_headline: Protests in Indonesia lead to deaths, military deployment

items.title: Thousands protest in Indonesia as military deployed in capital
items.standfirst: Thousands protested across Indonesia following anger over lavish perks for lawmakers, leading to six deaths and military deployment in Jakarta. While protests near the parliament were peaceful after President Prabowo Subianto called for an end by sundown, clashes erupted elsewhere, including in Gorontalo and Bandung, where police used tear gas and water cannons. Demonstrations also took place in Palembang, Banjarmasin, Yogyakarta, and Makassar.
items.content: Thousands protested across Indonesia following anger over lavish perks for lawmakers, leading to six deaths and military deployment in Jakarta. While protests near the parliament were peaceful after President Prabowo Subianto called for an end by sundown, clashes erupted elsewhere, including in Gorontalo and Bandung, where police used tear gas and water cannons. Demonstrations also took place in Palembang, Banjarmasin, Yogyakarta, and Makassar.

items.title: Twenty missing in Indonesia protests, rights group says
items.standfirst: Mass protests first erupted last week, prompted by anger over the perks and benefits given to lawmakers, including a controversial housing allowanceAt least 20 people are missing following violent protests that have gripped cities across Indonesia over the past week, a human rights group has warned.Mass protests first erupted on 25 August, prompted by anger over the perks and benefits given to lawmakers, including a controversial housing allowance. Public fury escalated further when a motorcycle taxi driver, 21-year-old Affan Kurniawan, was run over by a police vehicle at a protest site. Continue reading...
items.content: Mass protests first erupted last week, prompted by anger over the perks and benefits given to lawmakers, including a controversial housing allowanceAt least 20 people are missing following violent protests that have gripped cities across Indonesia over the past week, a human rights group has warned.Mass protests first erupted on 25 August, prompted by anger over the perks and benefits given to lawmakers, including a controversial housing allowance. Public fury escalated further when a motorcycle taxi driver, 21-year-old Affan Kurniawan, was run over by a police vehicle at a protest site. Continue reading...

items.title: Indonesia protests: president scraps lawmakers’ perks in bid to calm tensions
items.standfirst: Police set up checkpoints across Jakarta on Monday after deadly protests that have forced Prabowo Subianto to remove perks include a housing allowance worth 10 times the minimum wageIndonesian political parties have agreed to cut some lawmakers’ perks, including a controversial $3,000 housing allowance, the president said, as security measures were stepped up in an attempt to halt protests that have gripped the country for a week.President Prabowo Subianto, accompanied by leaders of eight Indonesian political parties, told a televised news conference in the capital, Jakarta, on Sunday that they had agreed to cut the housing allowance and suspend overseas trips for members of parliament. Continue reading...
items.content: Police set up checkpoints across Jakarta on Monday after deadly protests that have forced Prabowo Subianto to remove perks include a housing allowance worth 10 times the minimum wageIndonesian political parties have agreed to cut some lawmakers’ perks, including a controversial $3,000 housing allowance, the president said, as security measures were stepped up in an attempt to halt protests that have gripped the country for a week.President Prabowo Subianto, accompanied by leaders of eight Indonesian political parties, told a televised news conference in the capital, Jakarta, on Sunday that they had agreed to cut the housing allowance and suspend overseas trips for members of parliament. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Thousands protested across Indonesia due to anger over lawmakers' perks and benefits.
Six deaths were reported, and the military was deployed in Jakarta, the capital city.
Protests occurred in multiple cities, including Jakarta, Gorontalo, and Bandung.
Indonesian political parties agreed to cut some lawmakers' perks, including housing allowances.
At least twenty people are missing following the violent protests across Indonesia.

The parade marked 80 years since Vietnam's independence from French colonial rule.
